project_metadata.paper_title: Creating large, high-quality geospatial datasets from historical maps using novice volunteers
project_metadata.research_context: Crowdsourced digitisation of burial mounds from Soviet topographic maps in Bulgaria using mobile GIS; comparison of digitisation approaches (desktop GIS, crowdsourcing, machine learning)

timeline.2008-2016: TRAP catalogued 773 mounds (Kazanlak) and 431 mounds (Yambol) using pedestrian survey and manual digitisation
timeline.2010: Attempted desktop GIS digitisation with students (unsuccessful due to volunteer attrition)
timeline.2017-2018: FAIMS Mobile crowdsourced digitisation effort (2017: 5 rainy days concentrated work; 2018: sporadic work)
timeline.2017: Short field season with little time for training

location.study_area: Tundzha River watershed, Bulgaria (middle Yambol region and upper Kazanlak Valley)
location.map_coverage: Over 20,000 sq km of southeast Bulgaria

evidence.evidence_text: 10,827 mound features digitised from Soviet military topographic maps
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps.

evidence.evidence_text: Digitisation required 241 person-hours total
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: 57 person-hours from staff
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: 184 person-hours from novice volunteers
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: Error rate under 6%
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: Dataset ready for analysis with a few hours of processing
evidence.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

evidence.evidence_text: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds built in Bulgarian lands from Early Bronze Age through Middle Ages
evidence.verbatim_quote: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands from the Early Bronze Age through the Middle Ages (Shkorpil & Shkorpil, 1989, p. 20; Kitov, 1993, p. 42).

evidence.evidence_text: Mounds range from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5–20 m in height
evidence.verbatim_quote: They were constructed of earth and rubble, and range in size from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5–20 m in height (see Fig. 1).

evidence.evidence_text: TRAP catalogued 773 mounds in Kazanlak Valley between 2008-2016
evidence.verbatim_quote: Between 2008 and 2016, TRAP catalogued some 773 mounds in the Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in the Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey supported by manual digitisation of satellite imagery and maps.

evidence.evidence_text: TRAP catalogued 431 mounds in Yambol region between 2008-2016
evidence.verbatim_quote: Between 2008 and 2016, TRAP catalogued some 773 mounds in the Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in the Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey supported by manual digitisation of satellite imagery and maps.

evidence.evidence_text: Digitisation covered over 20,000 sq km of Soviet 1:50,000 topographic maps
evidence.verbatim_quote: (3) digitising mounds from over 20,000 sq km of Soviet military 1:50,000 topographic maps covering southeast Bulgaria, followed by ground-truthing (which continued through 2022).

evidence.evidence_text: Soviet maps available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs from 2008

location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.verbatim_quote: Available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs (from http://web.uni-plovdiv.bg/vedrin/index_en.html in 2008), each of these maps covers ca 400 sq km.

evidence.evidence_text: Each map tile covers ca 400 sq km

location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.verbatim_quote: Available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs (from http://web.uni-plovdiv.bg/vedrin/index_en.html in 2008), each of these maps covers ca 400 sq km.

evidence.evidence_text: Mound symbols occurred at average density of 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km)

location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.verbatim_quote: Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400.

evidence.evidence_text: Symbol counts ranged from 50 to 400 per tile

location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.verbatim_quote: Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400.

evidence.evidence_text: Records were relatively simple: point, record number, plus ten attributes

location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.verbatim_quote: The records we sought to create were relatively simple: a point for the feature, a record number, plus ten attributes.

evidence.evidence_text: Yambol region maps contained 1,000+ targeted symbols

location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.verbatim_quote: We knew that the maps of the Yambol region contained 1,000+ of these targeted symbols.

evidence.evidence_text: Students came from range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities.

evidence.evidence_text: Most students had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
evidence.verbatim_quote: Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods (unlike Podőr, 2015 or Can et al., 2021).

evidence.evidence_text: In 2010 desktop GIS effort, many volunteers quit and continuing volunteers required ongoing support
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our experience was much like that of other projects: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging; many quit and those who continued required ongoing support.

evidence.evidence_text: 2010 volunteer attrition combined with staff time demands rendered desktop GIS approach unsuccessful
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the end, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered this approach unsuccessful.

evidence.evidence_text: Simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitising after only minutes of training
evidence.verbatim_quote: As such, it stripped GIS functionality to its essentials, focusing on three tasks: layer selection, shape digitisation, and annotation, with validation and automation to improve data quality. Geospatial data preparation and management was relegated to staff, while a simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitising after only minutes of training.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile had previously been used with some success for a student-led ceramics recording project

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile had previously been used with some success for a student-led ceramics recording project (VanValkenburgh et al., 2018), and improved recording efficiency in other settings (Sobotkova et al., 2016).

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile improved recording efficiency in other settings

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile had previously been used with some success for a student-led ceramics recording project (VanValkenburgh et al., 2018), and improved recording efficiency in other settings (Sobotkova et al., 2016).

evidence.evidence_text: Digitisation took place at field bases in rural Bulgaria

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: Our digitisation took place alongside fieldwork, at field bases in rural Bulgaria.

evidence.evidence_text: Reliable internet connectivity could not be guaranteed in rural Bulgaria field bases

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: Reliable internet connectivity could not be guaranteed under these circumstances; a system that tolerated degraded network connectivity was required.

evidence.evidence_text: Only 2 of 12 students brought computers

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

evidence.evidence_text: None of the students brought mice

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

evidence.evidence_text: All 12 students had mobile devices

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

evidence.evidence_text: ESRI ArcGIS Collector and Survey123 had disadvantages: need to divide recording between apps, need for internet at setup stages, proprietary nature

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: The primary alternatives assessed, ESRI ArcGIS Collector (now succeeded by Field Maps) and Survey123, had a number of disadvantages, particularly the need to divide map-centric and form-centric recording between the two applications and reconcile the data later, the need for internet connectivity at crucial stages of project setup, and the proprietary nature of the system (Sobotkova et al., 2021, p. 20).

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile implementation included 7 stages: (1) staff modeled data/workflow, (2) developer customized system, (3) staff defined SRS and imported maps, (4) volunteers drew shapes, (5) volunteers transcribed attributes, (6) staff exported data, (7) staff did accuracy-checking

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: The stages of FAIMS Mobile implementation (Fig. 3) included: (1) project staff modelled the data and workflow to ensure that the final dataset met research needs, (2) a junior software developer worked with project staff to customise the system, (3) project staff defined a spatial reference system (SRS) and imported preprocessed historical maps, (4) volunteers drew a shape (usually a point) wherever they saw a target symbol and (5) volunteers transcribed attributes from the map, (6) project staff exported data using the FAIMS Mobile server, (7) project staff undertook a targeted accuracy-checking exercise.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile automated: applied SRS, rendered maps in workspace, provided layer management including data entry layer, enforced shape topology, displayed pre-defined controlled vocabularies, recorded creation time and author, maintained history of all changes, applied validation for record completeness, merged data from multiple devices, exported data in common formats

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: To support this workflow and make work easier for both project staff and participants, FAIMS Mobile automated a number of tasks and provided necessary capabilities. It applied the spatial reference system, rendered maps in the workspace, provided layer management (including a data entry layer), enforced shape topology, displayed pre-defined controlled vocabularies for attribute terms, recorded creation time and author for each record, maintained a history of all changes to data, applied validation to ensure record completeness, merged data from multiple devices, and exported data in common formats.

evidence.evidence_text: Digitisation interface had map view for geospatial data interactions and form view for attribute creation and editing

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: The digitisation interface itself was as streamlined as possible (see Figs. 4 and 5). Volunteers could toggle between a map view for geospatial data interactions and a form view for attribute creation and editing.

evidence.evidence_text: In the map view, volunteers could adjust layer focus and visibility, pan, and zoom; existing records could be searched, retrieved, inspected, and edited

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: In the map, they could adjust layer focus and visibility, pan, and zoom. Existing records could be searched, retrieved, inspected, and edited.

evidence.evidence_text: Project staff set up infrastructure and pre-processed and loaded required maps

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: Since project staff set up the infrastructure and pre-processed and loaded the required maps, volunteers were insulated from the friction of setup, layer management, data aggregation, export, and backup.

evidence.evidence_text: GIS features not needed for digitisation were hidden or eliminated

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: GIS features not needed for digitisation were hidden or eliminated.

evidence.evidence_text: Students needed only to be capable of selecting files from a list, panning and zooming a map, dropping a point, and filling out a form

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: Digitisation and metadata creation required no GIS or computing skills. Students capable of selecting files from a list, panning and zooming a map, dropping a point, and filling out a form were able to create data.

evidence.evidence_text: Only a few important controls were present: layer management, map navigation, record search and retrieval, shape and attribute creation and editing

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: Only a few important controls, including layer management, map navigation, record search and retrieval, and shape and attribute creation and editing, were present.

evidence.evidence_text: Users required almost no training

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: As a result, users required almost no training and could focus on the act of digitisation without being distracted by the technology used to accomplish it (Pascoe et al., 2000).

evidence.evidence_text: Exported data was consistent and complete, ready for analysis with minimal cleaning

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: Exported data was consistent and complete, ready for analysis with minimal cleaning.

evidence.evidence_text: Data adhered to key elements of FAIR principles, especially production of rich and plural metadata at time of creation (principles F2, R1.1–1.3)

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: This data adhered to key elements of the FAIR data principles, especially the production of 'rich' and 'plural' metadata at the time of data creation (principles F2, R1.1–1.3; GO-FAIR, 2017).

evidence.evidence_text: Code defining customisation, description, and user guide available on GitHub

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

evidence.verbatim_quote: The code defining this customisation, along with a description and user guide, can be found on GitHub (https://github.com/FAIMS/map-digitisation/releases/tag/map-dig-2018).

evidence.evidence_text: Success of approach became apparent early in 2017 field season, decision made to catalogue inputs vs outputs
evidence.verbatim_quote: The success of this approach became apparent early in the 2017 field season. At that point, we decided to catalogue inputs (time invested by staff and volunteers) versus outputs (features digitised) as part of a research program to evaluate digital approaches to fieldwork (e.g., Sobotkova et al., 2016).

evidence.evidence_text: Time measurements: student programmer via timesheets, volunteers via record creation timestamps, project staff via time-on-task journals
evidence.verbatim_quote: To measure inputs, we collated the amount of time spent by various participants in the process, including the student programmer who instantiated the customisation, the student volunteers who undertook the digitisation, and project staff who configured the system, supported volunteers, exported data, and checked for errors. Project records provided much of this data (timesheets from the programmer; record creation timestamps for students using the system), while project staff logged time-on-task for activities in journals.

evidence.evidence_text: Number of features digitised taken as the output measurement
evidence.verbatim_quote: We took the number of features digitised as the output.

evidence.evidence_text: Additional care taken in 2018 season to ensure complete records and confirm 2017 time estimates
evidence.verbatim_quote: Additional care was taken in the subsequent 2018 season to ensure these records were as complete as possible, and confirm 2017 time estimates for system set-up, administration, and support in the field.

evidence.evidence_text: 2017 customisation required 35 hours from undergraduate student programmer plus 4 hours from staff

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: For the first season of use (2017), creating the Map Digitisation customisation of FAIMS Mobile required 35 h from an undergraduate student programmer plus 4 h from staff ( Nassif-Haynes et al., 2021 ).

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: Monitoring file compression, upload to the server, and download to devices took an additional 2.5 h.

evidence.evidence_text: 2017 training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across entire season

evidence.verbatim_quote: Training and super vision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.

evidence.verbatim_quote: For the second season, adding additional validation to ensure pop ulation of latitude and longitude from GPS (see 'Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records ' below) took 1 h of development from the programmer.

evidence.verbatim_quote: In-field set-up required an hour (reusing the same equipment and system as the previous year)

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: map preparation 30 min

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: Across both seasons, customisation, setup, and supervision took about 51 h, including 36 h from the programmer and 15 from project staff.

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: Of this time, initial customisation and setup time before fieldwork was 44 h

evidence.verbatim_quote: while the time required during fieldwork to prepare and distribute maps, and then supervise participants, was 7 h.
