evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, re- examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

evidence.evidence_text: 2017: Map Digitisation used for 125.8 person-hours concentrated across 5 rainy days
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2017, it was used for a total of 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days

evidence.evidence_text: 2017: 8,343 features digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km)
evidence.verbatim_quote: during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km).

evidence.evidence_text: 2017: Average time to record a point feature was 54 seconds
evidence.verbatim_quote: The average time to record a point feature was 54 s, based on start and end times of feature creation as recorded by the devices (representing work time excluding pauses between records).

evidence.evidence_text: 2018: System used for 63.6 person-hours more sporadically
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2018, use was more sporadic; participants who stayed at the base for any reason sometimes undertook digitisation. The system was used for 63.6 person-hours

evidence.evidence_text: 2018: 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km)
evidence.verbatim_quote: with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km)

evidence.evidence_text: 2018: Average rate one record every 92 seconds
evidence.verbatim_quote: an average rate of one record every 92 s.

evidence.evidence_text: Total: 10,827 point features recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 seconds per record)
evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, 10,827 point features, mostly burial and settlement mounds, were recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 s per record).

evidence.evidence_text: 58 map tiles representing about 23,500 sq km were digitised
evidence.verbatim_quote: Fifty-eight map tiles representing about 23,500 sq km were digitised.

evidence.evidence_text: Dataset contained as many as 119,097 discrete values (11 attribute-value pairs per record, many captured automatically)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Since a single point record could be associated with 11 attribute-value pairs, the dataset contained as many as 119,097 discrete values (many captured auto matically).

evidence.evidence_text: 2010 desktop GIS digitisation effort produced 915 features
evidence.verbatim_quote: Although we did not maintain detailed volunteer time-on-task records, we know this effort produced a dataset of 915 features

evidence.evidence_text: 2010 effort required about 5-7 hours of staff training, support, and error-checking over three-week period
evidence.verbatim_quote: and required about 5 – 7 h of staff training, sup port, and error-checking over a three-week period (based on our field journals).

evidence.evidence_text: 2010: Most volunteers did not persevere long enough to repay their initial training time
evidence.verbatim_quote: Most volun teers did not persevere with the activity long enough to repay their initial training time.

evidence.evidence_text: 2010: One persistent student accounted for almost all digitised features
evidence.verbatim_quote: Indeed, one persistent student accounted for almost all the digitised features; without his perseverance, the digitisation effort would have failed entirely.

evidence.evidence_text: Automated testing suggested performance would degrade once approximately 3,000-6,000 records created
evidence.verbatim_quote: Automated testing of other custom isations suggested that performance would degrade once approximately 3,000 – 6,000 records had been created.

evidence.evidence_text: GPS coordinate extraction took 3-5 seconds with empty database
evidence.verbatim_quote: automated extraction of coordinates from GPS into the Latitude/Longitude and Northing/Easting fields, which took three to 5 s with an empty database

evidence.evidence_text: GPS coordinate extraction took as long as 30 seconds once device exceeded about 2,500 records
evidence.verbatim_quote: took as long as 30 s once a device exceeded about 2,500 records.

evidence.evidence_text: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records)

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

evidence.verbatim_quote: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records)

evidence.evidence_text: Data omissions: 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

evidence.verbatim_quote: including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions.

evidence.evidence_text: 2017: 192 records (2.3%) had empty latitude and longitude fields

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

evidence.verbatim_quote: Most occurred in 2017 when 192 records (2.3%) had empty latitude and longitude fields

evidence.evidence_text: 2017: 17 records (0.2%) missing specification of map symbol

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

evidence.verbatim_quote: and 17 (0.2%) were missing specification of the map symbol.

evidence.evidence_text: 2018: Only 13 spatial errors and 1 attribute omission (0.52%) after validation was added

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

evidence.verbatim_quote: Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%).

evidence.evidence_text: Only 2 data points could not be recovered from spatial omissions

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

evidence.verbatim_quote: Since the geodatabase pre served geometries, spatial omissions were corrected by re-extracting latitude and longitude; only two data points could not be recovered.

evidence.evidence_text: Quality assurance check found 49 errors from true count of 834 features (5.87% error rate)
evidence.verbatim_quote: found 49 errors from a true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate (see Table 3 ).

evidence.evidence_text: 42 errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Forty-two of these errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students).

evidence.evidence_text: 6 errors were double-marked (Student C digitised section twice)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Six were double-marked (Student C digitised a section of a map twice).

evidence.evidence_text: Only 1 classification error (similar symbol mistaken for benchmark)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Students made only one classification error (a similar symbol mistaken for a benchmark)

evidence.evidence_text: No outright false positives
evidence.verbatim_quote: and no outright false positives.

evidence.evidence_text: Individual student error rates ranged from 1.3% to 10.6%
evidence.verbatim_quote: Students ' individual error rates ranged from 1.3% to 10.6%.

evidence.evidence_text: Two fastest digitisers (Students A and B: 44-45 seconds per feature) had lowest error rates (1.3% and 2.9%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Note that the two fastest digitisers (Students A and B; 44 and 45 s per feature respectively) also had the lowest error rates (1.3 and 2.9%)

evidence.evidence_text: Two slowest digitisers (Students C and D: 61-73 seconds) had highest error rates (10.6% and 7.4%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: while the two slowest (Students C and D; 61 and 73 s) had the highest error rates (10.6 and 7.4%).

evidence.evidence_text: 35 of 49 false negatives from Student C failing to digitise 3 contiguous map sections
evidence.verbatim_quote: Moreover, 35 of the 49 false negatives were the result of Student C failing to digitise three contiguous sections of an assigned map.

evidence.evidence_text: Excluding Student C would cut cumulative error rate in half to 2.8%
evidence.verbatim_quote: These mistakes made his error rate of 10.6% an outlier; excluding Student C would have cut the cumulative error rate in half to 2.8%.

evidence.evidence_text: Project staff with desktop GIS experience could digitise at sustained rate of 60-75 features per staff-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: After brief workspace setup, project staff with desktop GIS experi ence could digitise at a sustained rate of 60 – 75 features per staff-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: At staff digitisation rate, 57 hours could have resulted in 3,420-4,275 staff-digitised features
evidence.verbatim_quote: At this rate, the 57 h of staff time devoted to set-up, support, and quality assurance for our crowdsourcing system could have resulted in some 3,420 – 4,275 staff-digitised features (see Table 4 ).

evidence.evidence_text: 2010 desktop GIS digitisation rate with volunteers was 130-180 features per staff-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: Had specialist project staff instead trained and supervised volunteers to use desktop GIS for digitisation, based on our 2010 digitisation rate of 130 – 180 features per staff-hour

evidence.evidence_text: With volunteers using desktop GIS, 57 hours might have produced 7,410-10,260 features
evidence.verbatim_quote: 57 h might have produced 7,410 – 10,260 features.

evidence.evidence_text: Crowdsourcing approach using FAIMS Mobile produced 190 features per staff-hour (57 hours produced 10,827 features)
evidence.verbatim_quote: By comparison, the 57 h of staff time required for our digitisation approach using a customisation of FAIMS Mobile produced 10,827 features, or about 190 features per staff-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: Only 21 of 57 hours from project staff; other 36 hours from outsourced student programmer
evidence.verbatim_quote: Only 21 of the 57 h needed to support the system came from project staff, while the other 36 h were completed by a student programmer for a modest cost (ca. AUD $2,000).

evidence.evidence_text: 21 internal staff hours represent digitisation rate of over 500 features per staff-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: Those 21 internal staff hours represent a digitisation rate of over 500 features per staff-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: In-field support for volunteers was only 7 hours, representing about 1,550 features per in-field staff-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: Across two seasons, in-field support for volunteers was only 7 h, representing about 1,550 features per in-field staff-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: Marginal cost 4.3 seconds of staff support per additional feature (13 hours in-field support and quality assurance)
evidence.verbatim_quote: This figure includes in-field support and quality assurance (13 h), and translates to 4.3 s of staff support per additional feature.

evidence.evidence_text: Preparing and distributing additional maps took only 6 minutes per map (6 hours for 58 maps)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Pre paring and distributing additional maps took only 6 min per map (6 h for 58 maps).

evidence.evidence_text: Adding another field season only costs 1 additional hour of setup time (based on 2018 redeployment)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Even adding another field season only costs one additional hour of setup time (based on our 2018 redeployment).

evidence.evidence_text: Urban Occupations Project reported 1,250 hours manual digitisation to create training data for road classification
evidence.verbatim_quote: This project reported 1,250 h of manual digitisation to create enough training data to classify roads visible in historical maps of the Ottoman Empire.

evidence.evidence_text: Urban Occupations ML expert spent 7 days testing and fine-tuning the model after preprocessing
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using this input, and after additional preprocessing and filtering, an ML expert spent seven days testing and fine tuning the model.

evidence.evidence_text: Urban Occupations ML output was ~300,000 km of roads digitised
evidence.verbatim_quote: The output was impressive: some 300,000 km of roads were digitised.

evidence.evidence_text: Crowdsourcing 241 hours produced 10,827 features at rate of 44.9 features/person-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: We spent 44 staff hours customising and deploying a streamlined geospatial system in FAIMS Mobile, 184 participant-hours digitising features, seven staff- hours directly supporting that digitisation, and six staff hours check ing for errors. These 241 h produced a dataset of 10,827 features, a rate of 44.9 features/person-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: At crowdsourcing rate, 1,300 hours (ML deployment time) would yield about 58,400 records
evidence.verbatim_quote: At that rate, the 1,300 h it took to deploy the ML approach taken by Can, Gerrits, and Kabadayi would yield about 58,400 records

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourced digitisation using FAIMS Mobile produced a large dataset efficiently
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps. This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

claims.claim_text: The resulting dataset was high-quality, consistent, well-documented, and analysis-ready
claims.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach required little training or supervision of students
claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features
claims.verbatim_quote: A conservative estimate based on our work suggests our crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features, but may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records.

claims.claim_text: Systems designed for field data collection can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers
claims.verbatim_quote: Furthermore, it indicates that systems designed for field data collection, running on mobile devices, can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers.

claims.claim_text: Burial mounds are an irreplaceable but endangered aspect of Bulgarian cultural heritage, making systematic recording urgent
claims.verbatim_quote: Burial mounds are an irreplaceable - but endangered - aspect of Bulgarian cultural heritage, making their systematic recording and registration an urgent undertaking for both research and cultural heritage management.

claims.claim_text: Manual digitisation using desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills
claims.verbatim_quote: Manually drawing and annotating shapes in historical maps using a desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills (Can, Gerrits, and Kabadayi 2021; Petrie et al., 2018; Jones & Weber, 2012).

claims.claim_text: ML requires specific programming expertise and familiarity with capabilities and limitations
claims.verbatim_quote: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation, but it requires specific programming expertise, and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML.

claims.claim_text: Training an ML algorithm requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance
claims.verbatim_quote: Training an algorithm, moreover, requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance (Bennett et al., 2014; Can & Kabadayi, 2021).

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing fills the gap between desktop GIS and ML approaches
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper argues that crowdsourcing offers advantages compared to alternative approaches under many, if not most, map digitisation scenarios.

claims.claim_text: The approach complements ML by requiring less technical expertise, time, and resourcing
claims.verbatim_quote: It complements Machine Learning (ML) and other automated approaches in that it requires less technical expertise, time, and resourcing to undertake.

claims.claim_text: The approach is suitable for projects with small to mid-sized data sources (100s-10,000s of features)
claims.verbatim_quote: Such an approach is suitable for projects working with small to mid-sized data sources (100s–10,000s of features) that do not warrant the investment needed for successful ML-based data extraction - as well as for exploratory work preceding automated analyses or the production of the training and quality assurance datasets needed for ML.

claims.claim_text: Desktop GIS manual digitisation has difficulty scaling due to restricted expert time and volunteer attrition
claims.verbatim_quote: Its principal limitations are difficulty of scaling the effort, particularly restricted time and availability of expert users to either undertake digitisation themselves, or to train and support novices to the extent required for efficient and accurate work (see also Jessop, 2007 for other challenges).

claims.claim_text: Naive use of ML is likely to produce biased or otherwise unreliable results
claims.verbatim_quote: Naive use of ML is likely to produce biased or otherwise unreliable results (Mehrabi et al., 2021; Schwemmer et al., 2020; Besse et al., 2018; Fuchs, 2018; Haas, 2017), even if pretrained image recognition models are used (Jiang et al., 2022).

claims.claim_text: The expertise necessary to use GIS has hindered collaboration between specialists and broader community

location.section: 1.4. Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: The expertise necessary to use a GIS has hindered collaboration between specialists and the broader community in the past (Jessop, 2007, p. 43).

claims.claim_text: Producing geospatial data from historical maps challenges novice users more than other data tasks

location.section: 1.4. Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Producing and manipulating geospatial data, even if it is limited to 'simple' activities like symbol digitisation (Goodchild, 2007), challenges novice users more than other data tasks.

claims.claim_text: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software

location.section: 1.4. Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software (Elwood, 2008b; Jones & Weber, 2012; Owen et al., 2009).

claims.claim_text: The 'digital divide' can be bridged through expert training and guidance but this scales poorly

location.section: 1.4. Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: This 'digital divide' can be bridged in part through more expert training and guidance of novice users (Owen et al., 2009, p. 24). Such an approach scales poorly, however; the supply of expert time available to any project is restricted and often oversubscribed, while the willingness of volunteers to learn specialised skills and software has limits.

claims.claim_text: Expert interaction can be profitably supplemented by developing 'useful' tools that combine utility with usability

location.section: 1.4. Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: While some expert interaction is unavoidable and desirable, it can be profitably supplemented by the development of 'useful' tools that combine 'utility' with 'usability' (Nielsen, 2012).

claims.claim_text: Mobile applications may be particularly suited to production of Volunteered Geographic Information

location.section: 1.4. Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Mobile applications may be particularly suited to the production of Volunteered Geographic Information (VGI).

claims.claim_text: Most potential users are familiar with mobile applications like Google Maps

location.section: 1.4. Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Most potential users are familiar with applications like Google Maps that utilise interactions via touch screen and integrated sensors like GNSS receivers and cameras.

claims.claim_text: Target symbols occurred at high density in the Soviet maps

location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

claims.verbatim_quote: Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400.

claims.claim_text: The digitisation task was relatively simple in terms of data complexity

location.section: 2.1. Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

claims.verbatim_quote: The records we sought to create were relatively simple: a point for the feature, a record number, plus ten attributes.

claims.claim_text: Student volunteers were novices with no prior GIS, archaeology, or cartography training
claims.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods (unlike Podőr, 2015 or Can et al., 2021).

claims.claim_text: Novice volunteers found learning desktop GIS challenging
claims.verbatim_quote: Our experience was much like that of other projects: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging; many quit and those who continued required ongoing support.

claims.claim_text: The 2010 desktop GIS digitisation effort was unsuccessful
claims.verbatim_quote: In the end, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered this approach unsuccessful.

claims.claim_text: The 2017 approach focused on implementing tools empowering volunteers to digitise independently
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, we focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile had proven track record in other archaeological recording contexts

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile had previously been used with some success for a student-led ceramics recording project (VanValkenburgh et al., 2018), and improved recording efficiency in other settings (Sobotkova et al., 2016).

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile working offline was a primary decision factor for choosing the platform

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: The decision to use mobile software, and FAIMS Mobile in particular, was based on several factors. First, FAIMS Mobile worked offline. Our digitisation took place alongside fieldwork, at field bases in rural Bulgaria. Reliable internet connectivity could not be guaranteed under these circumstances; a system that tolerated degraded network connectivity was required.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile met the functional requirements identified for geospatial software

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Second, this system met the functional requirements we identified for geospatial software. It supported the production of a customised map digitisation system with a simple UI and streamlined workflow, while still providing essential features including layer management, geometry creation and editing, capture and association of structured data, import and use of arbitrary rasters (scanned maps as geotiffs), automated metadata creation, and data validation.

claims.claim_text: Reusing FAIMS Mobile for digitization offered consistent working environment, reduced administrative load, leveraged experience, avoided additional costs

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Fourth, we were already using FAIMS Mobile for in-field legacy data verification, the project's main activity. Reusing the platform for digitisation offered a consistent working environment for users, reduced administrative load on staff, leveraged our experience with the platform, and avoided any additional hardware or software costs.

claims.claim_text: Student volunteers are accustomed to and prefer slippy-map touch-screen interfaces on mobile devices over desktop UI idiom

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Fifth, student volunteers are accustomed to, and even prefer, 'slippy-map', touch-screen interfaces on mobile devices over the point-and-click, desktop UI idiom.

claims.claim_text: Use of mobile interface would make it easier for students to learn the system and more likely to stick with digitisation

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: We believed that the use of the former would make it easier for students to learn the system, and more likely to stick with digitisation.

claims.claim_text: Mobile device choice reduced competition for limited computers, ESRI licenses, and desk space in the field

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

claims.claim_text: Mobile device choice allowed students to use their own devices

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

claims.claim_text: Authors preferred open-source software customised via code for redeployability and transparency advantages

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, we preferred the use of open-source software customised via code for its redeployability and transparency advantages.

claims.claim_text: No existing system met requirements off-the-shelf without significant customisation

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: No existing system met these requirements 'off-the-shelf', without significant customisation, and no competing product offered enough of an advantage to justify adopting a second geospatial recording system.

claims.claim_text: No competing product offered enough advantage to justify adopting a second geospatial recording system

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: No existing system met these requirements 'off-the-shelf', without significant customisation, and no competing product offered enough of an advantage to justify adopting a second geospatial recording system.

claims.claim_text: Digitisation of scanned maps deviated from the core FAIMS Mobile use-case of field data collection

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Digitisation of scanned maps deviated from the 'core' FAIMS Mobile use-case of field data collection, so it served both as a test of the platform's adaptability, and as an exploration of the potential benefits offered by repurposing mobile applications for field data capture to digitisation projects.

claims.claim_text: The project served as a test of FAIMS Mobile platform's adaptability

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Digitisation of scanned maps deviated from the 'core' FAIMS Mobile use-case of field data collection, so it served both as a test of the platform's adaptability, and as an exploration of the potential benefits offered by repurposing mobile applications for field data capture to digitisation projects.

claims.claim_text: The project was an exploration of potential benefits offered by repurposing mobile applications for field data capture to digitisation projects

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Digitisation of scanned maps deviated from the 'core' FAIMS Mobile use-case of field data collection, so it served both as a test of the platform's adaptability, and as an exploration of the potential benefits offered by repurposing mobile applications for field data capture to digitisation projects.

claims.claim_text: The approach moved activities requiring technical expertise to phases where specialists could contribute while simplifying tasks for volunteers

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

claims.verbatim_quote: This approach moved activities requiring technical expertise to phases where specialists could contribute, while simplifying the tasks assigned to student volunteers as much as possible.

claims.claim_text: The digitisation interface was streamlined as much as possible

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

claims.verbatim_quote: The digitisation interface itself was as streamlined as possible (see Figs. 4 and 5).

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile automated numerous tasks to make work easier for both project staff and participants

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

claims.verbatim_quote: To support this workflow and make work easier for both project staff and participants, FAIMS Mobile automated a number of tasks and provided necessary capabilities.

claims.claim_text: Volunteers were insulated from the friction of setup, layer management, data aggregation, export, and backup

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

claims.verbatim_quote: Since project staff set up the infrastructure and pre-processed and loaded the required maps, volunteers were insulated from the friction of setup, layer management, data aggregation, export, and backup.

claims.claim_text: Digitisation and metadata creation required no GIS or computing skills

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

claims.verbatim_quote: Digitisation and metadata creation required no GIS or computing skills.

claims.claim_text: Users could focus on the act of digitisation without being distracted by the technology

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

claims.verbatim_quote: As a result, users required almost no training and could focus on the act of digitisation without being distracted by the technology used to accomplish it (Pascoe et al., 2000).

claims.claim_text: Exported data was analysis-ready and adhered to FAIR principles

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

claims.verbatim_quote: Exported data was consistent and complete, ready for analysis with minimal cleaning. This data adhered to key elements of the FAIR data principles, especially the production of 'rich' and 'plural' metadata at the time of data creation (principles F2, R1.1–1.3; GO-FAIR, 2017).

claims.claim_text: Evaluation of inputs vs outputs was part of research program to evaluate digital approaches to fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: The success of this approach became apparent early in the 2017 field season. At that point, we decided to catalogue inputs (time invested by staff and volunteers) versus outputs (features digitised) as part of a research program to evaluate digital approaches to fieldwork (e.g., Sobotkova et al., 2016).

claims.claim_text: Staff time requirements for setup, support, and accuracy-checking were modest and manageable

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

claims.verbatim_quote: Across both seasons, customisation, setup, and supervision took about 51 h, including 36 h from the programmer and 15 from project staff.

claims.claim_text: Training and supervision during fieldwork required minimal staff time

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

claims.verbatim_quote: Training and super vision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.

claims.claim_text: Student volunteers achieved high digitisation velocity, especially in concentrated work sessions
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2017, it was used for a total of 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km). The average time to record a point feature was 54 s

claims.claim_text: Both concentrated and sporadic digitisation work sessions yielded valuable datasets
claims.verbatim_quote: The concentrated digitisation in 2017 was more productive than the intermittent work of 2018, but both seasons yielded large and valuable datasets utilising time that might otherwise have been lost

claims.claim_text: Concentrated digitisation in 2017 was more productive than intermittent work in 2018
claims.verbatim_quote: The concentrated digitisation in 2017 was more productive than the intermittent work of 2018

claims.claim_text: 2010 desktop GIS digitisation needed high-touch training and support during fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: The need for high-touch training and sup port by project staff during fieldwork, combined with a dislike for the activity on the part of volunteer digitisation further, despite attempting to do so.

claims.claim_text: Without one persistent student, the 2010 desktop GIS digitisation effort would have failed entirely
claims.verbatim_quote: Indeed, one persistent student accounted for almost all the digitised features; without his perseverance, the digitisation effort would have failed entirely. These problems reflect the high cognitive load desktop GIS places on novice users.

claims.claim_text: Performance degradation with large record counts was successfully mitigated through data export and reinstantiation
claims.verbatim_quote: Deteriorating perfor mance was mitigated by exporting all data and instantiating a new and empty version of the application. Since data structures were identical, aggregation of multiple exports was trivial.

claims.claim_text: Recoverable data omissions were low (2.06%) and mostly occurred before validation was added

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

claims.verbatim_quote: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records), including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions. Most occurred in 2017 when 192 records (2.3%) had empty latitude and longitude fields

claims.claim_text: Nearly all spatial omissions could be recovered from the geodatabase

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

claims.verbatim_quote: Since the geodatabase pre served geometries, spatial omissions were corrected by re-extracting latitude and longitude; only two data points could not be recovered.

claims.claim_text: Spatial data omissions resulted from software failure to populate latitude/longitude due to users moving through forms too quickly

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

claims.verbatim_quote: Spatial data omissions resulted from a failure of the software to populate the latitude and longitude fields from the application ' s Spa tiaLite geodatabase due to users moving through the forms too quickly

claims.claim_text: Validation added before 2018 season successfully addressed the latitude/longitude population problem

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

claims.verbatim_quote: Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%).

claims.claim_text: Overall digitisation accuracy was high (over 94% for processed maps)
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlike some volunteer digitisation projects, overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps.

claims.claim_text: Digitisation errors were predominantly false negatives and double-marking from contiguous map sections
claims.verbatim_quote: Forty-two of these errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students). Six were double-marked (Student C digitised a section of a map twice).

claims.claim_text: The pattern of errors (mostly false negatives and double-marked features from contiguous sections) made them relatively easy to identify and correct
claims.verbatim_quote: Moreover, the pattern of errors - mostly false negatives and double- marked features, mostly from contiguous map sections - made them relatively easy to identify and correct.

claims.claim_text: Best digitisers could be both fast and accurate, while poorest digitisers were often neither
claims.verbatim_quote: The best digitisers, furthermore, could be both fast and accurate, while the poorest digitisers were often neither fast nor accurate (see Tables 1 – 3 ).

claims.claim_text: Digitisation by project staff suitable only for smaller datasets (threshold ~3,420-4,275 features)
claims.verbatim_quote: Such a payoff threshold suggests that digitisation by project staff will be suitable only for smaller datasets. We could not have afforded to dedicate 3.5 – 4.5 weeks of staff time to digitisation.

claims.claim_text: Desktop GIS with volunteers almost competitive but assumes sufficient volunteer retention
claims.verbatim_quote: At the highest rate, desktop GIS digitisation using novice volunteers is almost competitive with the mobile applica tion approach we used. Scaling to this dataset size, however, assumes that enough volunteers could be retained to complete the work - something we were unable to do in 2010.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing approach produced about 190 features per staff-hour
claims.verbatim_quote: By comparison, the 57 h of staff time required for our digitisation approach using a customisation of FAIMS Mobile produced 10,827 features, or about 190 features per staff-hour.

claims.claim_text: Customisation of FAIMS Mobile can be outsourced more easily than other project activities
claims.verbatim_quote: First, customisation of systems like FAIMS Mobile can be outsourced more easily than other project activities. Only 21 of the 57 h needed to support the system came from project staff, while the other 36 h were completed by a student programmer for a modest cost (ca. AUD $2,000). Those 21 internal staff hours represent a digitisation rate of over 500 features per staff-hour.

claims.claim_text: Staff time during field season was scarce and valuable, making in-field efficiency crucial
claims.verbatim_quote: Second, given competing responsibilities, staff time during the field season was scarce and valuable. We could afford to invest in custom isation and setup beforehand, and error checking after, if it reduced staff obligations during fieldwork.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach has low marginal cost and scales well with dataset size
claims.verbatim_quote: Third, the marginal cost for each additional feature digitised is low. This figure includes in-field support and quality assurance (13 h), and translates to 4.3 s of staff support per additional feature. Thus, the larger the dataset, the more value is extracted from the setup and deployment time.

claims.claim_text: Qualitative factors (reduced staff stress, improved volunteer satisfaction) argue for mobile crowdsourcing approach
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, qualitative factors also argue for implementing a crowd sourcing approach using a mobile application. First, the need for staff to be continually available to troubleshoot problems with desktop GIS, lest digitisation stall, provided a continual source of stress and distraction. Second, when desktop GIS was used, volunteers perceived digitisation as a burden.

claims.claim_text: ML approaches require substantial time investment (minimum ~1,300 hours preparation) but pay off for large-scale projects
claims.verbatim_quote: This example, which appears to have required a minimum of about 1,300 h of preparation time alone, suggests that ML approaches are worthwhile for large-scale projects that benefit from the consistent symbology and style (as found in British and Ottoman imperial maps).

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing approach most suitable for datasets of 10,000-60,000 records
claims.verbatim_quote: To summarise in round numbers, a crowdsourcing approach like ours is most suitable for datasets numbering perhaps 10,000 – 60,000 records, assuming similar feature characteristics and data collection re quirements (see Table 5 ).

claims.claim_text: Below 10,000 records, desktop GIS approaches should be considered
claims.verbatim_quote: Below 10,000 records, approaches using desktop GIS should be considered.

claims.claim_text: Above 60,000 records, ML approaches should be contemplated if requisite expertise available
claims.verbatim_quote: Above 60,000 records, ML approaches should be contem plated, but only if a project has access to the requisite expertise.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing and ML approaches are complementary, not exclusive
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, since training a model requires a manually produced dataset and a degree of manual error-checking, a combination of ML and crowdsourcing approaches might serve even large-scale projects. A dataset big enough to justify ML will likely need a training dataset big enough to warrant crowdsourcing, especially if the features or back ground are variable. Once the crowdsourcing platform has been built, moreover, it can be used to produce additional datasets for error- checking to confirm the accuracy of the ML results. The approaches are not exclusive, therefore, but complementary.

claims.claim_text: Typical small, under-resourced history/archaeology projects can deploy collaborative geospatial systems but may struggle with ML
claims.verbatim_quote: Today, a typical project in history or archaeology - often small, under-resourced, and pursuing several research activities - may not be able to dedicate the personnel, infrastructure, or attention needed to incorporate ML successfully, but could deploy a collaborative geospatial system for crowdsourcing map digitisation.

claims.claim_text: A project with digital humanist or technologist at Software Carpentry skill level can customise and operate platforms like FAIMS Mobile
claims.verbatim_quote: A project with a digital hu manist or similar technologist with skills at the level of core Software Carpentry lessons ( TheCarpentries, 2023 ) can customise and operate a generalised platform such as FAIMS Mobile to implement an effective crowdsourcing system.

claims.claim_text: Purpose-built, lightweight, collaborative geospatial systems fill the gap between desktop GIS and ML approaches
claims.verbatim_quote: The complexity of full-featured, desktop GIS makes it difficult for novices to use, limiting the scale of digitisation. ML approaches require significant resources to implement and expertise to avoid failures arising from training bias or other pitfalls. Purpose-built, lightweight, collaborative geospatial data recording systems fill the gap between.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile facilitated offline, multi-user map-feature digitisation with minimal compromises
claims.verbatim_quote: Our use of FAIMS Mobile facilitated offline, multi-user map- feature digitisation, minimised post-processing, supported multiple data types, and produced high-quality data aligning with our methods and aims - with few compromises, work-arounds, or other technological distractions.

claims.claim_text: Comprehensive, FAIR-compliant dataset was ready for analysis with less than 2 hours of post-collection processing
claims.verbatim_quote: All collected data was available daily for review, and a comprehensive, FAIR-compliant dataset was ready for analysis with less than 2 h of processing after collection.

claims.claim_text: Simple expedients (redundant digitisation or peer review) would easily mitigate most errors
claims.verbatim_quote: An accuracy check by staff covering 7% of digi tised features indicated an error rate of under 6%; errors were predict able and would be easily mitigated by redundant digitisation by volunteers or volunteer peer review.

claims.claim_text: Approach becomes worthwhile for datasets of ~4,500+ features versus direct staff digitisation, ~10,000+ versus volunteer desktop GIS
claims.verbatim_quote: If staff time is the primary limiting resource, our approach becomes worthwhile for datasets no larger than about 4,500 features versus direct digitisation of features by expert staff, and no larger than about 10,000 features versus volunteer digitisation using desktop GIS.

claims.claim_text: Approach may pay off for fewer than 1,000 features if project staff time is at a premium
claims.verbatim_quote: It may pay off for fewer than 1,000 if project staff time is at a premium.

claims.claim_text: Approach remains most efficient for datasets up to at least 60,000 features
claims.verbatim_quote: It remains the most efficient approach for datasets up to at least 60,000 features, above which automated approaches like ML should be considered.

claims.claim_text: Approach can produce training datasets for ML and serve as quality assurance tool for ML outputs
claims.verbatim_quote: Our approach can also be used to produce the training datasets needed for ML, and as a tool for quality assurance for ML outputs.

claims.claim_text: Approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora
claims.verbatim_quote: This approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora, but our experience provides only a single data point for assessing the applicability of various digitisation approaches to histori cal maps.

claims.claim_text: More projects need to track and publish time requirements, error rates, and feature characteristics for map digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: More projects - whether they use manual or automated approaches - need to track and publish the expert and volunteer time required for setup, training, support, and quality assurance related to map digitisation, as well as digitisation speed, error rates and types, the characteristics of the features being digitised, and the complexity of information extracted.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Novice volunteers can rapidly achieve proficiency with well-designed mobile interfaces
trigger_text: students to begin digitising after only minutes of training
Training and super vision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season

trigger_locations.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system
3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The claim that crowdsourcing produced large datasets efficiently with little training (C001, C003) assumes that novice users can quickly become proficient. This assumption is implicit but necessary - if novices couldn't rapidly achieve proficiency, the minimal training wouldn't suffice. The evidence shows training took 'minutes' and 'almost no training', but doesn't explicitly state the assumption that such rapid proficiency is achievable for novices with appropriately designed interfaces.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Mobile touch-screen interfaces have lower cognitive load than desktop point-and-click interfaces for map digitisation tasks
trigger_text: These problems reflect the high cognitive load desktop GIS places on novice users
student volunteers are accustomed to, and even prefer, 'slippy-map', touch-screen interfaces on mobile devices over the point-and-click, desktop UI idiom
We believed that the use of the former would make it easier for students to learn the system

trigger_locations.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation
2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The core claim that mobile systems can serve as accessible participatory geospatial systems (C005) and that crowdsourcing required little training (C003) assumes mobile interfaces have inherently lower cognitive load. While the paper explicitly states desktop GIS has 'high cognitive load' and notes student preferences, it doesn't explicitly state the bridging assumption that mobile touch interfaces have lower cognitive load - this is implied by the comparison and the preference statements.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Quality of crowdsourced data is adequate for research purposes despite non-expert data collectors
trigger_text: overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps
The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing
Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents evidence of novice volunteers (no training) producing high-quality data (94% accuracy, analysis-ready), but doesn't explicitly state the bridging claim that connects these: that crowdsourced data quality from non-experts is research-adequate. This is crucial for C002 (high-quality dataset) and C005 (systems accessible to novice volunteers) - the implicit assumption is that 94% accuracy from novices is 'good enough', which is a judgment call not explicitly defended.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The 10,000-60,000 feature range threshold is generalizable beyond this specific project context
trigger_text: a crowdsourcing approach like ours is most suitable for datasets numbering perhaps 10,000 – 60,000 records, assuming similar feature characteristics and data collection re quirements
This approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora, but our experience provides only a single data point
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Core claims C004, C074, C084, and C086 all make specific quantitative threshold recommendations (10,000-60,000 features). However, these are based on a single case study. The paper acknowledges this is 'only a single data point' but still makes generalized recommendations. The implicit assumption is that this project's characteristics (feature density, symbol types, map quality, volunteer demographics, etc.) are representative enough to generalize. This assumption is somewhat qualified by 'assuming similar feature characteristics' but the degree of generalizability remains an unstated assumption.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Staff time is more valuable/constrained than volunteer time in archaeological fieldwork contexts
trigger_text: given competing responsibilities, staff time during the field season was scarce and valuable
We could afford to invest in custom isation and setup beforehand, and error checking after, if it reduced staff obligations during fieldwork
If staff time is the primary limiting resource
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The efficiency calculations and recommendations throughout the paper treat staff time as the primary constraint and optimization target. This reflects a disciplinary assumption in field archaeology that staff time (expert, scarce, expensive) is more valuable than volunteer time (abundant, willing). This assumption frames the entire efficiency analysis but is never explicitly stated - it's taken as given that minimizing staff hours is the primary goal, even if it increases total person-hours when volunteers are included.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Automation and validation features can compensate for novice user errors and lack of expertise
trigger_text: FAIMS Mobile automated a number of tasks and provided necessary capabilities
Use of controlled vocabularies, automation, and validation reduced errors
Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%)

trigger_locations.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system
3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper shows that adding validation dramatically reduced errors (from 2.3% to 0.52%) and that automation/validation features enabled novice users to produce high-quality data. However, it doesn't explicitly state the underlying assumption that such features can effectively substitute for user expertise. This assumption is critical for C002 (high-quality dataset from novices) and C003 (little training needed) - the implicit claim is that well-designed automation can compensate for lack of domain knowledge and technical skills.

research_designs.design_text: Comparative evaluation research design: assess crowdsourcing vs desktop GIS vs machine learning approaches for historical map digitisation

location.section: Introduction and 2.5. Evaluating the digitisation approach

research_designs.verbatim_quote: This paper argues that crowdsourcing offers advantages compared to alternative approaches under many, if not most, map digitisation scenarios. [...] At that point, we decided to catalogue inputs (time invested by staff and volunteers) versus outputs (features digitised) as part of a research program to evaluate digital approaches to fieldwork

research_designs.design_text: Efficiency-focused design using staff time as primary optimization criterion for comparing digitisation approaches
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This discussion, furthermore, fo cuses on our most limited resource: staff time. As such, the calculations below, which propose dataset size thresholds for various approaches, prioritise staff time required for digitisation.
expected_information_missing: Alternative optimization criteria (cost, total person-hours, data quality) not systematically evaluated

methods.method_text: Time-on-task measurement approach: measure inputs (staff and volunteer time) versus outputs (features digitised) to compare digitisation approaches
methods.verbatim_quote: To measure inputs, we collated the amount of time spent by various participants in the process, including the student programmer who instantiated the customisation, the student volunteers who undertook the digitisation, and project staff who configured the system, supported volunteers, exported data, and checked for errors. [...] We took the number of features digitised as the output.
expected_information_missing: Inter-rater reliability checks for time measurements

methods.method_text: Quality assurance sampling method: random selection of four maps for post-fieldwork accuracy checking

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

methods.verbatim_quote: re- examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

methods.method_text: Crowdsourced digitisation approach using novice volunteers with mobile GIS application during archaeological fieldwork
methods.verbatim_quote: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, we focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently.

methods.method_text: Mobile GIS platform selection method: systematic evaluation against functional requirements and field constraints

location.section: 2.3. Using a mobile application for map digitisation

methods.verbatim_quote: The decision to use mobile software, and FAIMS Mobile in particular, was based on several factors. First, FAIMS Mobile worked offline. [...] Second, this system met the functional requirements we identified for geospatial software.

methods.method_text: Seven-stage implementation workflow: staff modeling → developer customisation → map import → volunteer digitisation → data export → accuracy checking

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

methods.verbatim_quote: The stages of FAIMS Mobile implementation (Fig. 3) included: (1) project staff modelled the data and workflow to ensure that the final dataset met research needs, (2) a junior software developer worked with project staff to customise the system, (3) project staff defined a spatial reference system (SRS) and imported preprocessed historical maps, (4) volunteers drew a shape (usually a point) wherever they saw a target symbol and (5) volunteers transcribed attributes from the map, (6) project staff exported data using the FAIMS Mobile server, (7) project staff undertook a targeted accuracy-checking exercise.

protocols.protocol_text: Programmer time measurement: timesheets recorded hours spent on customisation and development
protocols.verbatim_quote: Project records provided much of this data (timesheets from the programmer

protocols.protocol_text: Volunteer time measurement: record creation timestamps from FAIMS Mobile system automatically captured time-on-task
protocols.verbatim_quote: record creation timestamps for students using the system

protocols.protocol_text: Staff time measurement: time-on-task journals manually logged staff activities
protocols.verbatim_quote: while project staff logged time-on-task for activities in journals

protocols.protocol_text: Accuracy checking protocol: desktop GIS setup, visual confirmation of feature digitisation against source maps, tabulation of errors and error rates

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

protocols.verbatim_quote: re- examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

protocols.protocol_text: Training protocol: volunteers received only minutes of training on mobile application interface
protocols.verbatim_quote: a simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitising after only minutes of training

protocols.protocol_text: Map assignment protocol: volunteers assigned specific map tiles to digitise
trigger_text: participants failed to digitise some assigned maps
Student C failing to digitise three contiguous sections of an assigned map
protocols.inference_reasoning: Multiple references to 'assigned maps' and 'assigned sections' indicate a formal assignment protocol existed, but the paper never describes how assignments were made, whether volunteers could choose maps, how workload was balanced, or how completion was tracked.

implicit_metadata.assessment_implication: Cannot determine if assignment strategy affected error patterns or efficiency

protocols.protocol_text: Validation rules protocol: controlled vocabularies, mandatory field requirements, and GPS coordinate population checks enforced data completeness

location.section: 2.4. Design and implementation of the recording system

protocols.verbatim_quote: displayed pre-defined controlled vocabularies for attribute terms, recorded creation time and author for each record, maintained a history of all changes to data, applied validation to ensure record completeness

protocols.protocol_text: 2018 enhanced validation protocol: added GPS coordinate population check to prevent empty latitude/longitude fields

location.section: 3.5.1. Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

protocols.verbatim_quote: Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%).

protocols.protocol_text: Map preparation protocol: tiling and pyramid creation for Soviet topographic GeoTIFF maps

location.section: 3.1. Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

protocols.verbatim_quote: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h.

protocols.protocol_text: Data export and aggregation protocol: export from multiple devices, merge using identical data structures
protocols.verbatim_quote: Deteriorating perfor mance was mitigated by exporting all data and instantiating a new and empty version of the application. Since data structures were identical, aggregation of multiple exports was trivial.

protocols.protocol_text: Performance mitigation protocol: export data and reinstantiate empty application when device exceeded ~2,500 records
protocols.verbatim_quote: automated extraction of coordinates from GPS into the Latitude/Longitude and Northing/Easting fields, which took three to 5 s with an empty database, took as long as 30 s once a device exceeded about 2,500 records. Deteriorating perfor mance was mitigated by exporting all data and instantiating a new and empty version of the application.

known_uncertainties: Additional protocols may exist but not documented in Methods section

extraction_notes.rationalization_actions: Focused Pass 4 - Verified all cross-references, validated explicit/implicit status. RDMAP extraction appears appropriate for paper scope.
